abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment shows highly
            unsatisfactory project outcomes, with highly unlikely
            sustainability, and negligible institutional development
            impacts. Regrettably, both performances by the Bank, and
            Borrower were also rated unsatisfactory. Lessons stipulate
            that: 1) major changes in fundamental project financial
            responsibilities MUST automatically trigger reappraisal; 2)
            supervision resources for the initial first two years of a
            new Bank project, are directly related to the quality of
            project implementation, as procurement procedures, covenant
            enforcement seriousness, and project ownership are
            established during such period. Unfortunately in this case,
            this was a major failure by the Bank; 3) the Bank must work
            with the Government of Indonesia to improve the legal,
            regulatory and policy frameworks governing land acquisition
            for public purposes - and preferably, on broader work on
            land tenure, and rights, as well as dispute resolution
            mechanisms, as envisioned under the upcoming Second Land
            Administration Project; and, 4) technical audits should
            become part of future projects, demonstrated by the
            usefulness of such audits in this project, though the
            Government, and all other participants failed to follow up
            on any of the findings. Further lessons recommend
            assessments of external shocks; improved enforcement of loan
            covenants; improved provisions for public information,
            namely for cases of fraud, and corruption; and, question the
            appropriateness of parallel financing arrangements for
            complex, integrated operations, such as this one.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Surabaya Urban Development Project
            will finance investments to support: (a) urban transport and
            traffic management with priority for public transport; (b)
            water distribution system improvements and expansion to
            increase coverage from the current 65% to 90% of the
            population; (c) storm drainage to reduce local flooding and
            related economic and social losses and expand the affordable
            supply of serviced land; (d) human waste collection and
            disposal for about 200,000 people and demonstrate the
            potential for conventional and low-cost off-site sanitation
            and cost recovery; (e) solid waste to increase coverage from
            the current 65% to 90% of the waste generated and improve
            collection and landfill disposal techniques with improved
            services for about 470,000 people; (f) kampung improvement
            to improve basic settlement facilities and living conditions
            for about 500,000 people in low income areas, land tenure
            for 100,000 households and building permits for about
            200,000 households; community participation in planning,
            implementing operating and maintaining improvements; and
            credit to low income households to install septic tanks, pit
            latrines, water supply connections and bathrooms and improve
            kitchens; (g) serviced, securely-tenured plots for
            resettlement; and (h) institutional development and
            capacity-building support.

732972.trustfund:

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Surabaya Urban Development
            Project : environmental assessment summary

abstracts.cdata!:
The Surabaya Urban Development Project
            is for urban infrastructure development and environmental
            improvement in Surabaya and includes all expenditure in
            Surabaya for the next 6 years on urban roads and transport,
            urban drainage, water supply, solid waste management,
            sanitation and kampung improvement.  It also includes
            improvements in urban management by institutional and human
            resources development, in financial management, in community
            participation and in land management, as well as technical
            assistance and training.  This report is an environmental
            assessment of the project.  It reviews the environmental
            impacts that each of the project component will have on the
            environment.  These impacts are: 1) resettlement of affected
            people; 2) traffic disruption; 3) encouragement of
            accelerated wetland development due to influence of nearby
            ring road; 4) changes to Brackish water ponds in East
            Surabaya; 5) change to agriculture due to conversion of
            irrigation channels to drainage; 6) expansion of landfill at
            Keputih; 7) continued operation of Kenjeran Beach Landfill;
            8) air pollution and health risks to residents near new
            depots or transfer stations; and 9) air and noise pollution
            due to digging sewer pipe trenches. The report also presents
            a description of the project, the baseline data, an analysis
            of the alternatives, the mitigation plans, monitoring and
            evaluation, institutional needs and, finally, public participation.

docna.cdata!:
Indonesia - Surabaya Urban Development
            Project : environmental assessment summary

display_title.display_title:
Indonesia - Surabaya Urban
            Development Project : environmental assessment summary
